item.title: Tesla competitor BYD enters the Romanian market with four models. How are the prices?
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
The first BYD dealerships in Romania have opened in Bucharest, hosted by Țiriac Auto and DAB Auto

The post Tesla competitor BYD enters the Romanian market with four models. How are the prices? appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
BYD (Build Your Dreams), the world’s leading electric vehicle manufacturer, has officially entered the Romanian market, offering an initial lineup of fully electric and plug-in hybrid models equipped with the advanced DM-i (Dual Mode – intelligent) technology.

At the top of the range is the SEALION 7, a fully electric SUV that accelerates from 0 to 100 km/h in just 4.5 seconds. It boasts a maximum range of up to 502 km (WLTP) thanks to BYD’s revolutionary Blade Battery. The SEALION 7 is priced at €40,590 (VAT included), and the premium version is €49,590.

Also debuting locally is the SEAL U DM-i, a plug-in hybrid SUV powered by BYD’s Super DM technology. This model offers a combined electric and fuel range of over 1,000 km on a full charge and tank. Prices start at €34,890 and go up to €41,890 for the high-end Design version.

The ATTO 2, BYD’s third SUV for the Romanian market, also features the Blade Battery and Cell-to-Body architecture seen in the SEALION 7 and SEAL models. It comes with a 1.5-liter gasoline engine and starts at just €22,590 (VAT included). The top-tier version adds €3,000 to the base price.

BYD’s sole sedan offering in Romania is the SEAL, which shares the high-tech construction of the SEALION 7 but with a more aerodynamic profile, enabling a range of up to 570 km (WLTP). Prices begin at €37,590, climbing to €42,590 for the superior variant.

The first BYD dealerships in Romania have opened in Bucharest, hosted by Țiriac Auto and DAB Auto. The company plans to expand its retail footprint to over 30 sales points nationwide by the end of 2025, including cities like Ploiești, Brașov, Iași, Cluj-Napoca, Timișoara, Constanța, Pitești, and Craiova.

Founded in 1995, BYD made history last year by becoming the first car manufacturer in the world to produce over 10 million electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles (PHEVs). The company employs more than 110,000 engineers and technicians and files an average of over 40 patent applications daily.

The post Tesla competitor BYD enters the Romanian market with four models. How are the prices? appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.

item.title: New car registrations fell by 24% in April. Electric cars are down 70%!
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
In the first 4 months of 2025, new car registrations reached 43,361 units. This is a decrease of 5.1% compared to the same period in 2024

The post New car registrations fell by 24% in April. Electric cars are down 70%! appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
New car registrations fell 24% last month compared to April 2024 to 9,910 units, with registrations of pure electric cars down 70% compared to the same month last year, according to APIA data.

Domestic manufacturer Dacia topped the sales charts with 2,325 units. It was followed by Toyota with 997 units, Skoda with 842 units, Volkswagen with 642 units, Renault with 565 units, Hyundai with 499 units, BMW with 488 units, Ford with 486 units, Mercedes-Benz with 468 units, and Suzuki with 322 units.

With 886 units sold, the Dacia Duster was the best-selling new car model in April 2025. It was followed by Dacia Logan – 678 units, Dacia Sandero – 558 units, Toyota Corolla – 312 units, Skoda Octavia – 296 units, Ford Kuga – 245 units, Renault Clio – 243 units, Toyota RAV4 – 229 units, Hyundai Tucson – 222 units and Toyota Yaris Cross – 166 units.

The post New car registrations fell by 24% in April. Electric cars are down 70%! appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.

item.title: World Bank slashes Romania’s 2025 growth forecast to 1.3%, lowest in region
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
In response to challenges, the World Bank report emphasizes the critical need for Romania to accelerate structural reforms within its economy

The post World Bank slashes Romania’s 2025 growth forecast to 1.3%, lowest in region appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
The World Bank has significantly lowered its forecast for Romania’s economic growth in 2025, projecting a rate of just 1.3%. This revised figure represents a notable downgrade and positions Romania with the lowest anticipated growth rate among the countries in the Europe and Central Asia (ECA) region.

This updated projection is a substantial cut from the World Bank’s previous estimates and falls considerably short of the Romanian government’s more optimistic growth targets. The international financial institution attributes the dimmer outlook to a combination of factors, including heightened global uncertainty, rising trade barriers, weaker demand from key trading partners, and persistent domestic inflationary pressures.

Looking slightly ahead, the World Bank projects a modest acceleration in Romania’s economic growth to 1.9% in 2026. However, the lowered forecast for the upcoming year underscores the significant hurdles Romania must overcome in maintaining a robust economic trajectory amidst a complex and uncertain global economic climate.

The post World Bank slashes Romania’s 2025 growth forecast to 1.3%, lowest in region appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.

item.title: Chinese automaker Chery accelerates European push with official entry into Romanian market
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
The distribution agreement will enable the local sale of TIGGO SUV models, starting in the second half of 2025

The post Chinese automaker Chery accelerates European push with official entry into Romanian market appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
Chinese automotive giant Chery has officially launched its operations in Romania, marking a significant step in the company’s accelerated expansion strategy across Europe. AUTO ITALIA has been assigned as the official importer of the Chery brand in Romania.

The distribution agreement will enable the local sale of TIGGO SUV models, starting in the second half of 2025. In 2025, Chery will prioritize the launch of the fourth-generation TIGGO7 and TIGGO8, both powered by Chery Super Hybrid (CSH).

Romania becomes a key market in the region for the brand, which has seen consistent growth in recent years, reaching over 2.6 million vehicles sold globally in 2024, a 38% increase compared to the previous year.

With a presence in over 110 countries and regions and more than 15 million global users, of which 4.5 million are outside China, Chery continues its international expansion and will launch its mass-produced TIGGO family models across several European markets later this year.

Chery’s European R&D Center in Frankfurt will play a critical role in aligning Chery’s technologies with European regulatory frameworks and market dynamics, supporting adaptive development and enabling the creation of vehicles that are tailored to meet 100% European standards.

Founded in 1997, Chery is one of China’s largest automotive companies. It operates eight global R&D centers and employs over 18,000 engineers worldwide. The brand is China’s leading passenger car exporter and was recently included in the Fortune Global 500 (ranked 385th as of August 2024).

item.title: E-Commerce Boom Drives Growth in Industrial and Logistics Sectors
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
Between 2025 and 2029, Romania’s e-commerce market is expected to generate €47.8 billion

The post E-Commerce Boom Drives Growth in Industrial and Logistics Sectors appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
Romania is rapidly emerging as a key player in the e-commerce landscape of Central and Eastern Europe, with the sector showing no signs of slowing down. In 2024, the Romanian e-commerce market reached a staggering €7.7 billion, and experts predict that it will continue to grow at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 7.5%, reaching new heights by 2029.

As Romania’s e-commerce market expands, it is reshaping the logistics and industrial sectors. The demand for industrial and logistics spaces has surged, with the largest e-commerce players occupying approximately 1 million square meters of space. This represents around 10% of the national logistics stock, placing e-commerce companies among the top five largest occupiers in the country.

Key cities such as Bucharest-Ilfov, Timișoara, Cluj-Napoca, and Brașov are emerging as major hubs, thanks to their developed infrastructure and strategic access to critical transport corridors. These areas are increasingly attracting investment as companies seek to meet growing demand for faster and more efficient delivery services.

The growth of e-commerce is also influencing cost dynamics. Labor costs within Romania’s logistics sector remain relatively competitive compared to other European countries, making it an attractive option for investors looking to tap into the region’s expanding market.

However, with the increasing demand for logistics space, rental prices have climbed, reaching as much as €4.5 per square meter per month, depending on location and the quality of facilities, Cushman & Wakefield Echinox reports.

Between 2025 and 2029, Romania’s e-commerce market is expected to generate €47.8 billion. The fastest-growing categories in this boom include grocery, home appliances, beauty products, automotive goods, and hobby-related items, as consumers increasingly shift their spending toward online retail.

The number of online shoppers in Romania has seen a sharp rise. In 2024, 10.2 million people made purchases online—representing 55% of the country’s internet users. A significant growth opportunity in the digital market relates to the low number of companies which sell online in Romania.

Their share is of almost 50% vs. the European Union average, despite the fact that the country can boast an internet penetration rate of 94% and more than 50% of the population is doing online shopping.

item.title: Gadgets and toys instead of traditional new clothes for Easter
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
Interest is even higher among younger Romanians, with more than 41% of Gen Z and Millennials prioritising this type of product

The post Gadgets and toys instead of traditional new clothes for Easter appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
This Easter, the online shopping basket looks different as consumer preferences continue to shift towards digital and practical products. Thus, gadgets, small appliances and tech-related gifts such as toys are among the most popular online purchases for the holiday season, chosen by nearly 4 in 10 Romanians, according to a survey conducted by Cargus.

Clothing and footwear, once essential symbols of Easter, have slipped to second place with only 27% of respondents choosing them. Some 22% will order food and drink online for the Easter meal and 17% will buy holiday-themed home and garden decorations. Notably, over a third of respondents (37%) say they don’t make any Easter-specific online purchases.

While home delivery remains the top choice for most Romanians (61%), alternative options are gaining ground. Some 44% of respondents say they also use fixed delivery points, with adoption significantly higher among younger consumers.

item.title: Romanian buyers prefer used cars from Germany, France, and Belgium
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis

The main reasons behind this trend are better vehicle maintenance and lower wear and tear. Cars from […]

The post Romanian buyers prefer used cars from Germany, France, and Belgium appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
In 2024, most of the vehicles imported into Romania came from Western Europe. According to carVertical, 32.3% of these vehicles were imported from Germany, 17% from France, 11.7% from Belgium, 11.2% from Italy, and 7% from the Netherlands.

The main reasons behind this trend are better vehicle maintenance and lower wear and tear. Cars from countries like Germany, Sweden, and the Netherlands are typically in better condition, thanks to more stringent service schedules and superior road infrastructure.

On the other hand, used cars imported from Poland showed a higher risk of odometer tampering, with 14.3% of the checked vehicles displaying discrepancies. Other countries with notable odometer fraud rates included the US (13.9%), Spain (10.5%), Italy (10.3%), and Denmark (8.5%).

However, identifying odometer manipulation can be tricky. A car might arrive from abroad with a specific mileage, only for local sellers to alter the odometer reading in an effort to increase its market value.

item.title: The largest private healthcare provider in Finland acquires Regina Maria network
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
Finland’s largest private healthcare provider, Mehiläinen, acquired Romania’s Regina Maria network and Serbia’s leading private healthcare provider, MediGroup, for a whopping $1.4bn. With a 115-year history and a presence in five European countries, in its home market of Finland as well as in Sweden, Germany, Lithuania and Estonia, the Finnish group is the fastest-growing company […]

The post The largest private healthcare provider in Finland acquires Regina Maria network appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
Finland’s largest private healthcare provider, Mehiläinen, acquired Romania’s Regina Maria network and Serbia’s leading private healthcare provider, MediGroup, for a whopping $1.4bn.

With a 115-year history and a presence in five European countries, in its home market of Finland as well as in Sweden, Germany, Lithuania and Estonia, the Finnish group is the fastest-growing company in the healthcare sector.

The group serves more than 2.2 million customers annually and reported revenues of EUR 2,063.5 million in 2024, an increase of 11.5% compared to 2023. The group’s operations include over 890 clinics or medical facilities and a network of more than 37,000 healthcare professionals.

With more than 11,000 employees and a presence in every county in Romania, Regina Maria Healthcare Network has a portfolio of nearly 1 million subscribers and approximately 13,000 corporate partners. It is one of the largest private premium healthcare providers in the country.

Founded in 2013, MediGroup has grown from a few hundred employees to a team of over 2,500 dedicated professionals. With a nationwide presence, it has a network of 16 health centers and polyclinics, a general hospital, 3 specialist hospitals, 4 diagnostic centers, and more than 75 laboratories.

item.title: Salary map and the top jobs with the highest salaries in the 1st quarter
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
The highest salaries in the first quarter were received by employees in Bucharest, where the average net salary was 5,500 lei per month across all sectors of activity and all levels of experience, according to Salario platdform data. 5,000 lei was the average salary in Cluj, the county with the second highest salary in Romania. […]

The post Salary map and the top jobs with the highest salaries in the 1st quarter appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
The highest salaries in the first quarter were received by employees in Bucharest, where the average net salary was 5,500 lei per month across all sectors of activity and all levels of experience, according to Salario platdform data. 5,000 lei was the average salary in Cluj, the county with the second highest salary in Romania.

Next come Brasov with an average of 4,700 lei, Timis with 4,600 lei and Iasi with 4,400 lei. The lowest salaries were reported by employees in Giurgiu (3,520 lei), Vrancea (3,700 lei), Covasna (3,800 lei), Gorj (3,850 lei) and Tulcea (4,000 lei).

In a ranking of the best-paid jobs, the IT sector continues to top the list, with a net average of 7,500 lei per month. In second place is the oil and gas industry, with an average of 6,000 lei net per month, followed by Engineers – 5,400 lei, and Audit / Consultancy – 5,300 lei.

On the other hand, the lowest average salaries are found in sectors where most of the employees are newcomers. These include the textile industry (3,500 lei), beauty parlours and clinics (3,700 lei), retail trade (3,750 lei) or call centres / BPO (3,900 lei).

item.title: To avoid worrying about bills, 7 out of 10 homeowners want energy autonomy
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
Many of them also have or plan to buy an electric car and ensure maximum compliance, and in the future install heat pumps to achieve total energy independence

The post To avoid worrying about bills, 7 out of 10 homeowners want energy autonomy appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
Romanians interest in photovoltaic plants has increased 2 times in the first months of the year compared to the same period in 2024, and most homeowners (70%) want to cover their total monthly electricity consumption to achieve energy autonomy, according to data from Kilowat.

Thus, they install, from their own funds, photovoltaic panels of at least 5-6 kW and up to 15 kW, investing between 20,000 and over 50,000 RON in such systems, to reduce their energy bill by at least 70%.

For example, a 5-6 kW photovoltaic system with 5 kW storage, which costs 20,000 RON (4,000 euros), can provide total autonomy to a household with an average consumption of 300-500 kW/month.

Main investors in photovoltaic plants are families with average and above-average incomes, who live in houses of at least 80-100 sq m and have a high number of energy consumers in the household. They usually live in urban and peri-urban areas, especially Bucharest-Ilfov, Cluj, Sibiu, Timișoara, and Constanța.

The post To avoid worrying about bills, 7 out of 10 homeowners want energy autonomy appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
